page.title: 07THE TANFIELD RAILWAY
page.content: All that is left of the{TANFIELD {RAILWAY }is the line between Marley Hill Engine Shed and Sunniside.A few local amateurs began the enormous task of preserving the railway in 1971. Originally built in 1725,this railway superceded the shorter Ravensworth waggonway which was built in the early seventeenth century. The Railway was used for moving coal to the River Tyne.The track was eight miles long between Dunston on Tyne and South Moor.At first the waggons were pulled by horses.Some horses were replaced in 1839 by stationary steam engines.By 1881 all horses were replaced and locomotives introduced. The Tanfield Railway ceased to operate between Tanfield and Sunniside in 1962 and between Watergate and Whickham in 1964.The last section closed in 1980.
